meta_data.title: Understanding and Addressing Hierarchy-Imbalance in Semi-supervised Node Classification with Hyperbolic Geometry
meta_data.abstract: In real-world graphs, the hierarchical structure is a significant topological property. Understanding the hierarchy-imbalance issue is crucial for semi-supervised node classification. This paper presents a novel framework, \\modelname, which explores the hierarchy-imbalance from a hyperbolic geometric perspective. The framework utilizes hyperbolic geometric embedding to capture the implicit hierarchy and adjust classification margins, and uses curvature to enhance message-passing efficiency. Extensive experiments demonstrate the superiority of \\modelname across various datasets.

relate work.related papers: Hamilton et al. (2017), Zhang et al. (2020), Chen et al. (2021), Song et al. (2022)

high_level_summary.summary of this paper: The paper discusses the impact of the hierarchy-imbalance issue on semi-supervised node classification, introducing a framework called \\modelname. Using hyperbolic geometry, it adjusts classification margins and uses local curvature to enhance message-passing efficiency, outperforming existing methods on multiple datasets.
high_level_summary.research purpose: To explore and address the hierarchy-imbalance issue in semi-supervised node classification using a hyperbolic geometric perspective.
high_level_summary.research challenge: Effectively measuring hierarchy-imbalance and adjusting classification boundaries in complex hierarchical graphs.
high_level_summary.method summary: Using hyperbolic geometric embeddings to capture implicit hierarchy and curvature-aware message-passing to enhance information propagation in graphs.
high_level_summary.conclusion: The proposed framework \\modelname greatly improves prediction accuracy in semi-supervised node classification by addressing hierarchy-imbalance issues.

Method.description: \\modelname leverages hyperbolic geometry to address imbalance by adjusting decision boundary margins with hyperbolic embeddings and enhancing message-passing using local curvature.
Method.problem formultaion: Imbalance in classified nodes in hierarchical graphs impacts effective learning.
Method.feature processing: Hyperbolic geometric embedding captures the node hierarchy implicitly.

Experiments.setup: Implementation in PyTorch Geometric; GNN backbones with 2-layer depth; Different hierarchy-level setups.
Experiments.results: \\modelname consistently outperforms all baselines, especially on hierarchical tasks.
Experiments.performance: Improved classification accuracy significantly with hierarchy-aware margin and message-passing techniques.
Experiments.analysis: Observed significant class distribution effects using hyperbolic geometry and curvature-aware techniques.

conclusion.summary: \\modelname addresses the hierarchy-imbalance issue in graph node classification through hyperbolic geometry and curvature-aware techniques, achieving substantial improvements in classification tasks.
